title: 106_hr1444
content:
The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area and Secretary of the Interior. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. Projects under the Program may include fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features to mitigate impacts on fisheries in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. Projects may involve the development, improvement, or installation of fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features. States will conduct inventories to determine the need and priority for these projects. The Secretary will prioritize projects with a total cost of less than $5,000,000. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM. Non-Federal participation is voluntary, and the Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply. Federal projects on U.S. land are nonreimbursable.

SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS. Projects will be evaluated based on benefits to native fish species, water diversion size, funding availability, cost effectiveness, and additional biological or water system benefits.

SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. Projects must meet Secretary and State requirements, and have approval from all relevant entities. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and use available data to determine project eligibility. The non-Federal share of costs for projects under the Program on non-Federal land is 35%. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land, easements, and other resources. The value of these contributions will be credited towards the non-Federal share. Non-Federal participants are responsible for operating and maintaining the project, while the Federal Government has its own responsibilities. Non-Federal facilities must cover costs for project operation and maintenance. Federal Government is responsible for costs on Federal land or facilities. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from other sources for the same purpose. 

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those to be completed with remaining funds, and recommended Program changes based on project outcomes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005. Limitations: 25% max funds per state, 6% max for administrative expenses. Waiver possible for unused funds.
